abstract.t: This memo defines the Publish Option for the Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP). This Option is employed by a CoAP end-point to control the authority delegation of one of its resources to another end-point. All the phases of the authority delegation process (setup, renewal, cancellation) are controlled by a simple RESTful protocol.

This memo also introduces the 'proxies' Web Linking relation type, to be used by a CoAP proxy to explicitly advertise the resources that it can serve either from cache or by forwarding the client request upstream.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This memo defines the Publish Option for the Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP).

The Publish Option is used by a sleepy end-point (SEP) to temporarily delegate the authority of one of its resources to another, always on, node which is typically a proxy but doesn't need to be necessarily.

The SEP is given a simple RESTful messaging protocol that enables the setup, renewal and cancellation of the authority transfer. The whole process is driven by the SEP, which may actually never need to listen or to keep any state.

This memo also introduces the 'proxies' Web Linking relation type. This new relation -- complementing the default 'hosts' relation -- can be used by a CoAP proxy to explicitly advertise the resources that it can serve either from cache or by forwarding the client request upstream.
The 'proxies' relation works in concert with the Publish Option to enable SEP discovery even while SEP is off-line.

section.title: Requirements Language and Motivation
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .
This memo reuses the terminology introduced in , and aims at meeting the objectives stated in its Section 4 via an entirely in-protocol solution.

section.title: Publish Option
section.t: The Publish Option enables a SEP to temporarily (i.e. for a specified "lease" time) delegate the authority of one of its hosted resources to a Proxy node that will start to behave as the origin for the Publish'ed resource. This allows a SEP to use the Proxy as the rendezvous point for one-way SEP to SEP signaling.

section.title: Publishing a Resource
section.t: The origin server publishes one of its hosted resources, specified by the enclosed Proxy-URI, by PUT'ing it to the Proxy with a Publish Option attached. The Publish Option value specifies the CoAP methods that clients are allowed to use on the resource (see ).

The example in shows a delegation where the GET and PUT methods are allowed while POST and DELETE are explicitly prohibited, meaning that the resource can be read and updated by clients, but it can't be deleted nor created.

figure.artwork: P S | PUT | Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res |<--------+ Publish: 0x60 | r | Content-Format: text/plain | | ETag: 0xabcd | | Max-Age: 1200 | 2.01 | +-------->| | |

section.t: The Proxy, which is voluntarily charged by the resource owner to act as the delegated origin for the "lease" time specified by Max-Age, replies with a 2.01 if the authority transfer succeeds. An exact duplicate of the submitted representation is created, and from now on it can be accessed using the original URI provided that clients request it through the delegated Proxy. If the Publish operation does not succeed (e.g. because the Proxy does not support Publish), then the origin transfer fails, and an appropriate response code is returned (e.g. 4.02 Bad Option).

An ETag MAY be supplied as a metadata to be included in responses involving the Publish'ed representation. If no Max-Age is given, a default of 3600 seconds MUST be assumed. The Max-Age value, either implicit or explicit, determines the lifetime of the origin delegation. When Max-Age is elapsed, the Proxy MUST delete the Publish'ed resource value and fall back to its usual proxying function.

The Publish Option is critical and MUST be present in the request only. If the Proxy does not recognize it, a 4.02 (Bad Option) MUST be returned to the client. If the Option value is not correctly formatted (see ), a 4.00 (Bad Request) MUST be returned to the client. The Publish Option is not Safe-to-Forward, and neither is a Cache-Key.

Since the 2.01 is emitted, and for the duration of the delegation, any client wishing to access the resource can do so by making a Proxy-URI request to the Proxy node, which shall then serve the resource off from its own storage.

The Proxy MUST save the identity of the resource Publish'er and MUST use it to distinguish "maintainance" operations such as update or explicit deletion, from "regular" access to the published resource by third parties.

An interesting outcome of this communication strategy is that the SEP may really never need to listen on its radio interface. However, ignoring the response status code from Proxy is not a safe practice and is not encouraged.

section.title: Updating a Resource
section.t: In order to update the delegated resource state, the SEP shall send the very same request (except possibly the representation value) to the Proxy, which in turn replies with a 2.04 Changed status code in case the update operation succeeds. If the operation fails, e.g. because the request comes from an end-point different from the Publish'ing SEP, a suitable status code is returned (e.g. 4.01 Unauthorized).

figure.artwork: P S | PUT | Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res |<--------+ Publish: 0x60 | r | Content-Format: text/plain | | ETag: 0xdcba | | Max-Age: 1200 | 2.04 | +-------->| | |

section.title: Unpublishing a Resource
section.t: The delegation of a given resource can be explicitly revoked by the SEP at any time before the lease time expires, by issuing a DELETE request to the Proxy hosting the resource duplicate with a Publish Option with value 0x00.

figure.artwork: P S | DELETE | Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res |<---------+ Publish: 0x00 | | | 2.02 | +--------->| | |

section.t: On successful deletion of the delegation, a 2.02 Deleted response code is returned by the Proxy. On error a suitable status code is returned.

section.title: Value Format
section.t: Each of the higher 4 bits is a flag field indicating whether the associated CoAP method (respectively: POST, GET, PUT and DELETE) is allowed on the Publish'ed resource. The lower 4 bits are reserved and MUST be set to 0.
The 0x00 value is used to explicitly revoke the delegation (see .) and MUST NOT be used for any other purpose of the Option.

If the delegated Proxy receives a request for the Publish'ed resource with a method that is not compatible with the mask supplied by the SEP, it MUST respond with a 4.05 (Method Not Allowed) response code.

section.title: The 'proxies' Relation Type
section.t: The 'proxies' Web Linking relation type tells the requesting entity that the carried resource, identified by an absolute URI-Reference, is reachable through a Proxy-URI request made to the responding end-point.

section.title: Examples

figure.artwork: P C | GET | Uri-Path: .well-known |<--------+ Uri-Path: core | | Uri-Query: rel="proxies" | 2.05 | +-------->| <http://sleepy.example.org/res>; rel="proxies" | | ...

list.t: C GETs a "proxied" resource from P:

figure.artwork: P C | GET | |<--------+ Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res | | | 2.05 | +-------->| "res" data... | |

section.t: It's up to P to decide whether to serve coap://sleepy.example.org/res from its store/cache, or to forward the request to the origin at coap://sleepy.example.org.

section.title: Implicitly
section.t: The resource metadata are implicitly pulled off from the Publish'ed representation. Basically, the Proxy works out the ct and sz attributes by inspecting Content-Format and the request payload size.

section.title: Explicitly
section.t: The resource metadata are explicitly Publish'ed to the same Proxy-URI used for the sibling resource, either in a separate request/response cycle (see ),

figure.artwork: P S | PUT | Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res |<--------+ Publish: 0x60 | <meta> | Content-Format: application/link-format | | | 2.01 | +-------->| | |

section.t: or atomically, within the same Publish operation, e.g. by using the Multipart Content-Format to aggregate one (or even more than one) representation(s) together with the application/link-format entry (see ).

figure.artwork: P S | PUT | Proxy-URI: coap://sleepy.example.org/res |<--------+ Publish: 0x60 | [mp] | Content-Format: application/multipart+publish | | ETag: 0xabcd | | Max-Age: 1200 | 2.01 | +-------->| | |

section.t: Note that the former () is non-atomic, and limited to only one representation of the resource; the latter () is atomic and supports multiple Content-Format's for the published resource.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This section identifies Threats (T) and related countermeasures (C).

list.t: C: use strong auth to identify SEP.
C: strong auth to identify SEP.
C: use strong auth to identify SEP + quota limit.
T: Inject fake copies of the resource by a 3rd party.

C: use delegation scheme that bundles the identities of the SEP and the Proxy, together with the resource being delegated. A third party must be able to verify SEP and Proxy identities, maybe offline, and check the resource fingerprint.

section.title: Securing the Delegation
section.t: (Sketch) SEP signs the identity of the delegated Proxy and a fingerprint of the resource (both data and meta), and bundles it up with the resource itself, maybe in a MP envelope (TBD define signed resource). Client verifies the resource is indeed from the SEP (check signature), and it has been served by the intended origin, in the validity frame of the delegation. Apparently, there's an issue with hierarchical caching: the resource can't be served from a downstream Proxy different from the one that was originally delegated unless each proxy in the delivery chain wraps the received message with its own credentials?
